awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Conference: Supporting inclusive and sustainable research infrastructure for systematics (SISRIS) by connecting scientists and their specimens.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create a conference-based workshop and symposium at the annual Association for Southeastern Biologists conference (March 2023; Winston-Salem, North Carolina) and the Botany 2023 conference (July 2023; Boise, Idaho) to train scientists in new computational skills and practices that build inclusive and sustainable infrastructure for collections-based research. Recent advances in web-based software now make it possible for taxonomic experts to receive greater professional recognition and citation of their digitized biological specimens and identifications. Use of these software tools can increase the visibility of scientists as well as modernize the professional rewards system to support the development of taxonomic expertise. However, creating a self-sustaining cycle of specimen attribution and citation that leverages this new software requires greater awareness by collections-based researchers and cultural change in how taxonomic expertise is credited. At the heart of this change is ensuring that the names of the people who collect and identify biological research specimens are disambiguated and associated with globally unique identifiers. Accurate people-data are an essential part of the vision for an extended specimen network because they link groups of specimens across institutions and uncover events in the history of science. The project will develop research infrastructure that is more inclusive, because taxonomic contributions by all people would be acknowledged explicitly, and sustainable, because improved recognition of taxonomic expertise would help build and sustain this scientific workforce in the US.

Workshops will include 75 participants and the symposia will feature 12 diverse speakers, who will reach an anticipated audience of 190 collections-based researchers. Speakers will deliver case-studies that illustrate integrating people-data into the digital infrastructure of biological research collections. The workshop will comprise four hours of instruction about the use of globally unique identifiers for people within the biodiversity informatics open-access software services of Bionomia and the Global Biodiversity Information Facility and their interaction with Open Researcher and Contributor ID, Wikidata, and Zenodo. Participants will learn how to use these tools as part of documenting their own collections-based research activities and as a means of community-level change in how taxonomic expertise is acknowledged. For the latter objective, participants will practice attributing US herbarium specimens to historical people from underrepresented groups, which will increase the visibility of these scientists’ intellectual contributions to biological research collections as well as improve the curation of digitized US biological research collections. Extensive plans are included to ensure broad participation, including outreach methods to underrepresented groups and support to participants in the form of travel stipend and dependent-care assistance. Workshop and symposium outcomes will be assessed rigorously and shared with the broader systematics community as a model for improving how taxonomic expertise is credited.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The SISRIS project team conducted three half-day workshops and trained botanical collectors, herbarium workers, scientists from botanical and other disciplines, and students from the systematics community how to improve the quality of data in natural history collection records. The SISRIS workshops trained 51 different individuals from across all career stages about the rationale for using unique identifiers for collectors and identifiers of natural history specimens and how to use Bionomia and other software services that interact with this platform (ORCID, GBIF, Wikidata, Zenodo) to accomplish this work. This included crediting people for their past work, particularly underrepresented groups, and improving the accuracy of ambiguous Mrs. John Smith naming trends of the past. Not only did this support future collections-based researchers, but it allowed living people to assist with the copious amount of specimens that should be associated with deceased collectors. The work completed by workshop participants improved the records for 90,492 herbarium specimens. Specimens from 135 different collectors were attributed, including 95 deceased collectors from underrepresented groups. Participants felt the SISRIS project was inter-disciplinary, in that it combined historical research about people with topics related to best-practices of specimen curation and advances in systematic research. 

At the end of the workshop, most participants reported substantial gains in their understanding of the use of biodiversity informatic tools. The gains in understanding for Bionomia (82 percentage points gained), GBIF (25%), Wikidata (69%), ORCID (49%), and Zenodo (29%) show that training was effective. Participants reported high levels of motivation to continue using these tools and sharing their knowledge with others, as measured directly after the workshop and 60 days later.

An extraordinarily positive effect of the SISRIS project is the degree to which participants shared new knowledge or skills months after the workshop. 93% of participants shared with other botanical colleagues or students. 62% of participants shared with at least one other non-botanical but academic colleague or student, and 67% of participants have shared with other non-academic acquaintances such as family and friends. SISRIS workshop skills have been shared with hundreds of individuals who did not attend the workshop, facilitating dissemination and a broader impact.

Long-term effects of training on the participants' use of the biodiversity informatics tools were measured two months afterward. 73% of participants continued using Bionomia. Participants reported having “increased greatly” their use of Bionomia (53%), GBIF (22%), Wikidata (24%), ORCID (31%) and Zenodo (18%) since taking the workshop. 

In addition to training workshops, two research symposia were held at the annual meeting of the Association of Southeastern Biologists (ASB) on March 23–26, 2023 in Winston-Salem, NC and July 22–26, 2023 in Boise, ID at the national botanical conference, Botany 2023. Symposia speakers highlighted case-studies where linking people and specimens has yielded novel research insights and increased the visibility of the contributions of collectors from underrepresented groups. The 14 speakers drawn from across the United States and Canada contributed talks from 14 diverse institutions ranging from small liberal arts colleges to internationally renowned museums. Two speakers were from HBCU’s; eleven speakers were women. There were 140 different individuals who attended the symposia as in-person audience members. It is unknown how many viewed the recorded talks asynchronously, many of which were posted to the SISRIS webpage following ASB 2023 and all of which were recorded and live-streamed within the Botany2023 conference platform.

The SISRIS program is a notable model for dissemination of best-practices for improving how taxonomic expertise is measured, made visible and acknowledged by others.
